definition: blood is thicker than water/fig. family ties are closer than social relations
water/river/liquid/beverage/additional charges or income/(of clothes) classifier for number of washes

sentences.english: Still, blood is thicker than water.
Family members always stand by one another because blood is thicker than water.
sentences.chinese: 家庭成員都會彼此扶持，因爲血濃於水。

sentences.english: Qualcomm situation in the heart, blood is thicker than water.
They say that blood is thicker than water, that our relatives are more important to us than others.
sentences.chinese: 人們說血濃於水，即我們的親屬比別人對我們更重要。

sentences.english: Because other reasons can cause blood is thicker than water relations?
sentences.chinese: 仍然由於其它的原因能導致一個血濃於水關係？

sentences.english: Mr. Jones hires relatives to work in his store. Blood is thicker than water.
sentences.chinese: 瓊斯先生僱用親戚在店裏工作，血濃於水嘛。

sentences.english: Literature has close relation with solitude.
sentences.chinese: 文學和孤獨的關係血濃於水。

sentences.english: Don't you realise that blood is thicker than water?
sentences.chinese: 難道你們不明白血濃於水嗎？

sentences.english: Blood is thicker than water. If you have friends who know your heart, distance cannot keep you apart.
sentences.chinese: 血濃於水，如果你有真心的朋友，距離也隔不斷你們。

sentences.english: With affection the blood is more invaluable and important than water.
sentences.chinese: 爲何血濃於水，因有愛在其中。

sentences.english: Blood is thicker than water. Our veins are bounded .
E. g. I can't report my brother's crime – after all, blood is thicker than water.
sentences.chinese: 我不能通報我兄弟所犯下的罪行，畢竟血濃於水。

sentences.english: Proof indeed, that blood is thicker than water.
sentences.chinese: 事實再次證明，血濃於水。

sentences.english: Blood is thicker than water, and Bill was part of the dynasty .
sentences.chinese: 血濃於水，而比爾究竟是福特王朝的一個成員。

sentences.english: Another proverb is "Blood is thicker than water".
sentences.chinese: 另外一個諺語是“血濃於水”。

definition: lit. as close as lips and teeth (idiom); closely related/interdependent
mutual exchange of assistance (idiom)/to benefit from each other's strengths and make up each other's shortfalls/to reciprocate with material assistance/scratch each other's back
to regard it as an honor (idiom)
to love Hong Kong (usually implying that one also supports the PRC government)
anger against a common enemy (idiom); joined in opposition to the same adversary
highest common factor HCF/greatest common divisor GCD
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
to work with a common purpose (idiom); to make concerted efforts/to pull together/to work as one
millions of people all of one mind (idiom); the people united
